revision.text:
{{Infobox comedian |name = Ken Jeong |image = Ken Jeong March 2015.jpg |caption = Jeong at [[South by Southwest|SXSW]] 2015 |birth_name = Kendrick Kang-Joh Jeong |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1969|7|13}} |birth_place = [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]], U.S. |alma_mater = [[Duke University]]
[[UNC School of Medicine|University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]] ([[Doctor of Medicine|MD]]) |medium = [[Stand-up]], [[film]], [[television]] |genre = [[Improvisational comedy]], [[sketch comedy]], [[observational comedy]] |active = 1997–present |notable_works = ''[[Community (TV series)|Community]]''
''[[The Hangover Trilogy]]''
''[[Knocked Up]]''
''[[Role Models]]''
''[[Ride Along 2]]''
''[[Dr. Ken]]'' |home_town = [[Greensboro, North Carolina]] |spouse = {{marriage|Tran Ho|2004}} |children = 2 |website = {{URL|http://kenjeong.com}} }} '''Kendrick Kang-Joh Jeong''' (born July 13, 1969) is an American stand-up comedian, actor and former physician.Ancestry.com. U.S. Public Records Index, Volume 1 [database on-line]. Provo, UT, US: Ancestry.com Operations, Inc., 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.vulture.com/2011/05/the_suprisingly_earnest_ken_je.html|title=The Surprisingly Earnest Ken Jeong on the Secret Messages of The Hangover|publisher=Nymag|work=Vulture.com|date=May 23, 2011|accessdate=March 18, 2013|author=Barshad, Amos}} He is best known for playing Ben Chang on the sitcom ''[[Community (TV series)|Community]]'' and the [[gangster]] Leslie Chow in [[The Hangover (film series)|''The Hangover'' film series]]. He was the lead in the ABC sitcom ''[[Dr. Ken]],'' in which he was also the creator, writer, and executive producer. Jeong is a licensed physician, {{cite web |url=https://search.dca.ca.gov/details/8002/A/65869/833fe63788fbbfdf85673d2f42f77918 |title=Medical Board of California - Licensing details for A 65869 |publisher=dca.can.gov}} but has stopped practicing in favor of his acting career.{{cite web|url=http://www.redbookmag.com/fun-contests/celebrity/ken-jeong-interview|title=A Side of ''Community'''s Ken Jeong You Haven't Seen|first=Nicole|last=Yorio|work=Redbook}} ==Early life and education== Jeong was born in [[Detroit]] to [[South Korea]]n immigrants.{{cite news|last=Lopez|first=Robert|title=Greensboro native finds funny bone in movie|work=News & Record|date=June 19, 2009|url=http://www.news-record.com/content/2009/06/19/article/greensboro_native_finds_funny_bone_in_movie|accessdate=2010-03-22}}{{cite news|last=Lee|first=Chris|title=Doctor provides best medicine|work=The Columbus Dispatch|date=June 10, 2009|url=http://www.dispatch.com/live/content/arts/stories/2009/06/10/2_HANGOVER_FUNNYGUY.ART_ART_06-10-09_D5_OQE4LU0.html|accessdate=September 13, 2009}}{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/kenjeong/status/650861736254291969|title=Ken Jeong on Twitter: "@S0fak1ng83 born in Detroit, moved to NC when I was 4. My father got his PhD in Economics from Wayne State."|author=Ken Jeong|date=October 4, 2015|accessdate=August 31, 2016}} Jeong was raised in [[Greensboro, North Carolina]], and attended [[Walter Hines Page High School]],{{cite news|last1=Lee|first1=Luaine|title=Ken Jeong was a doctor, and now he plays one on TV|url=http://www.greensboro.com/blogs/gotriad_extra/ken-jeong-was-a-doctor-and-now-he-plays-one/article_791035ac-1d7e-515f-b5af-b4937440e441.html|accessdate=15 December 2016|work=Greensboro News & Record|date=1 October 2015}} where he took part in the [[Quiz Bowl]] team, played [[violin]] in the orchestra, and was elected to student council.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} He graduated at 16 and his achievements earned him Greensboro's Youth of the Month award. Jeong graduated from [[Duke University]] in 1990 and obtained his [[M.D.]] at the [[UNC School of Medicine|University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill School of Medicine]] in 1995. ==Career== ===Medicine=== Jeong completed his [[internal medicine]] residency at [[Ochsner Medical Center]] in New Orleans while developing his [[stand-up comedy]].{{cite web|title=Dr. Ken Jeong|url=http://iamkoream.com/ken-jeong-is-good-for-us|work=Justforlaughs|accessdate=July 18, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130806090658/http://iamkoream.com/ken-jeong-is-good-for-us/|archivedate=August 6, 2013|df=}} Jeong is a [[Medical license|licensed]] physician in [[California]],State of California Department of Consumer Affairs, Physician License #65869 for Jeong, Kendrick Kang-Joh, Issued 07/01/1998, Expires 05/14/1995, [https://www.breeze.ca.gov/datamart/selSearchTypeCADCA.do?from=loginPage DCA BreEZe License Verification] but no longer practices medicine, having given it up in favor of his acting career. ===Acting=== Jeong won the Big Easy Laff-Off in 1995, of which [[NBC]] president [[Brandon Tartikoff]] and [[The Improv]] founder [[Budd Friedman]] were judges, and they both urged Jeong to move to Los Angeles.{{cite web|title = 'Hangover' actor saw his career start in New Orleans -- at Ochsner|url = http://blog.nola.com/mikescott/2009/06/ken_jeong_is_a_real.html|website = NOLA.com|accessdate = 2015-10-24}} He began performing regularly at [[the Improv]] and [[Laugh Factory]] [[comedy club]]s. After moving to Los Angeles, he initially practiced medicine for several years as a physician at a [[Kaiser Permanente]] hospital in [[Woodland Hills, Los Angeles|Woodland Hills]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/ken-jeong-how-ditch-medicine-817478|title=Ken Jeong: How to Ditch Medicine for a Career in Comedy and Diagnose Castmates|date=August 27, 2015|accessdate=8 September 2015}} Jeong's background in theater and improv started while he was still a medical student in North Carolina. He was a regular at open mic nights in the Raleigh-Durham circuit, performing at Charlie Goodnights in Raleigh and Tootie’s Durham Comedy Club. He also emceed The Comedy Spot programming series on Duke University campus 1992 and 1993 (produced by his friend by coincidentially same-first named Korean-American, Kendrick Jahng) opening for Margaret Cho, Jeff Dunham and others. His stand up work has led to several television appearances, including NBC's ''[[The Office (U.S. TV series)|The Office]]'', HBO's ''[[Entourage (U.S. TV series)|Entourage]]'' and ''[[Curb Your Enthusiasm]]''. He made his film debut in [[Judd Apatow]]'s ''[[Knocked Up]]'' as Dr. Kuni, which proved to be his breakout performance. From that point forward he was able to transition from medicine into a full-time career in the entertainment industry. Subsequently, he has appeared in ''[[Pineapple Express (film)|Pineapple Express]]''; ''[[Role Models (film)|Role Models]]'' as King Argotron; ''[[All About Steve (film)|All About Steve]]''; ''[[The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard]]''; ''[[Couples Retreat]]''; and as [[The Hangover (film)#Cast|Mr. Chow]] in ''[[The Hangover]]'', ''[[The Hangover Part II]]'', and ''[[The Hangover Part III]]''. He co-starred in ''[[Zookeeper (film)|Zookeeper]]'' and ''[[Transformers: Dark of the Moon]]'', released in summer 2011. Jeong played [[Señor Chang|Señor Ben Chang]] on the NBC sitcom ''[[Community (TV series)|Community]]'' and was nominated for the show's "Male Breakout Star" at the [[2010 Teen Choice Awards]]. He was nominated for two 2010 [[MTV Movie Awards]], winning the award for ''Best WTF Moment'' and for [[MTV Movie Award for Best Villain]] for ''The Hangover''. In fall 2010, [[Adidas]] basketball began a wide-ranging marketing campaign in which he starred as "Slim Chin", alongside NBA stars [[Dwight Howard]] and [[Derrick Rose]]. On May 22, 2011, he hosted the ''[[2011 Billboard Music Awards]]'' in Las Vegas on ABC{{cite web|url=http://asiapacificarts.usc.edu/article@apa?fareast_movement_will_perform_at_ken_jeong-hosted_billboard_music_awards_16721.aspx|title=Far*East Movement will perform at Ken Jeong-hosted Billboard Music Awards|publisher=Asia Pacific Arts|date=May 12, 2011}} and was featured in a [[Hands Only CPR]] PSA campaign from the [[American Heart Association]] on June 15, 2011.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n5hP4DIBCEE|title=Ken Jeong AHA Hands-Only CPR video|date=June 15, 2011|accessdate=July 18, 2013}} Jeong won a [[Streamy Award]] for "Best Guest Appearance" for ''[[Burning Love (Web series)|Burning Love]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.streamys.org/blog/2012/12/nominations-are-announced-for-3rd-annual-streamy-awards|title= Nominations Are Announced For 3rd Annual Streamy Awards|work=The Streamy Awards|date=December 17, 2012|accessdate=July 18, 2013}} In 2013, he appeared in [[Michael Bay]]'s ''[[Pain & Gain]]'' (2013), as Johnny Wu, a motivational speaker,{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/ken-jeong-hangover-michael-bay-pain-gain-308842|work=The Hollywood Reporter|first=Borys|last=Kit|title='Community' Star Ken Jeong Joins Michael Bay's 'Pain and Gain' (Exclusive)|date=April 5, 2012|accessdate=July 18, 2013}} and returned, in a significantly expanded role, as [[The Hangover (film)#Cast|Mr. Chow]] in ''[[The Hangover Part III]]''.{{cite news|last1=Siegel|first1=Tatiana|last2=Belloni|first2=Matthew|date=July 12, 2012|title=Ken Jeong Signs on for Expanded Role in 'Hangover: Part III' (Exclusive)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/ken-jeong-hangover-3-expanded-role-348694|work=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=September 7, 2012}} In an unusual, if informal, partnership, [[Jamie Foxx]] and Jeong have each agreed to star in movies written and produced by the other. Foxx has agreed to take a lead role in a new movie Jeong will produce called ''After Prom''. Jeong will star in ''All-Star Weekend'', a comedy Foxx is developing at his production company about two friends who find themselves fans of opposing NBA stars.{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2012/oct/10/entertainment/la-et-mn-jamie-foxx-and-ken-jeong-agree-to-trade-movies-20121010|title=Jamie Foxx and Ken Jeong agree to trade movies|work=Los Angeles Times|date=2012-10-10|accessdate=July 18, 2013}} In 2015, Jeong starred, wrote, and executive produced the pilot of his new [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] medical comedy, ''[[Dr. Ken]]'', as a frustrated HMO doctor juggling his career, marriage and parenting, but succeeding at none of them. On May 7, 2015, the series was ordered by ABC to debut in the [[2015–16 United States network television schedule|'15–'16 TV season]] starring Jeong, [[Suzy Nakamura]], [[Dave Foley]], [[Tisha Campbell-Martin]] and [[Jonathan Slavin]].{{cite web|url=http://iamkoream.com/abc-orders-ken-jeongs-comedy-dr-ken-to-series/|title=ABC Orders Ken Jeong’s Comedy ‘Dr. Ken’ to Series|date=May 8, 2015|accessdate=September 8, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150930121603/http://iamkoream.com/abc-orders-ken-jeongs-comedy-dr-ken-to-series/|archivedate=September 30, 2015|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/medical-comedy-starring-communitys-ken-770179|title=Medical Comedy Starring 'Community's' Ken Jeong Scores ABC Pilot Order|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=2015-02-10|accessdate=September 8, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://abc.go.com/shows/dr-ken/news/updates/dr-ken-series-premiere-20150610 |title=Dr. Ken Series Premiere Date Announced |work=ABC Go |date=2015-06-10 |accessdate=September 8, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150904013942/http://abc.go.com/shows/dr-ken/news/updates/dr-ken-series-premiere-20150610 |archivedate=September 4, 2015 |df= }} ==Personal life== Jeong's wife, Tran Ho, is [[Vietnamese American]], a [[family physician]] and a [[breast cancer]] survivor.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/ken-jeong/mothers-day-for-my-wife_b_858775.html|title=For My Wife, in Celebration of Mother's Day|first=Ken|last=Jeong|date=May 7, 2011|publisher=Huffington Post}}{{cite news|last=Deerwester|first=Jayme|title=Ken Jeong transitions from doctor to in-demand jokester|work=USA Today|date=September 3, 2009|url=http://iamkoream.com/ken-jeong-is-good-for-us/#comment-4016|accessdate=18 July 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130806090658/http://iamkoream.com/ken-jeong-is-good-for-us/#comment-4016|archivedate=6 August 2013|df=}}{{cite web|author=Margarita|title=Dr. Ken Jeong Thanks Wife Dr. Tran Ho During MTV Movie Awards|url=http://spotlight.vitals.com/2010/06/dr-ken-jeong-wife-dr-tran-ho-mtv-movie-awards|work=Vitals|date=June 7, 2010|accessdate=July 19, 2013}} Jeong became engaged to Tran Ho around 2003 or 2004.{{youtube|id=1oGTgyhPuUw|title=Standup Dr. Ken Old BET Comic}} They have twin daughters (born 2007).{{cite news |publisher=[[The Huffington Post]] |title=For My Wife, in Celebration of Mother’s Day |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/ken-jeong/mothers-day-for-my-wife_b_858775.html |date=5 July 2011 |accessdate=25 September 2016}} ==Filmography== Role |- |2007 |''What's It Gonna Be?'' |[[Million Dollar Strong]] |- |2011 |''[[I Like How It Feels]]'' |Himself |- |2016 |''[[Boombox (song)|Boombox]]'' |[[Laura Marano]]'s Director |- |2016 |La La (Visual) |Himself |} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Ken Jeong}} * {{Official website|http://www.kenjeong.com/}} * {{IMDb name|0421822|Ken Jeong}} * {{Allmovie name|598002|Ken Jeong}} {{Portal bar|Biography|Film in the United States|Asian Americans|South Korea}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jeong, Ken}} [[Category:1969 births]] [[Category:20th-century American comedians]] [[Category:21st-century American comedians]] [[Category:20th-century American male actors]] [[Category:21st-century American male actors]] [[Category:Male actors from North Carolina]] [[Category:American male actors of Korean descent]] [[Category:American male comedians]] [[Category:American male film actors]] [[Category:American male voice actors]] [[Category:American people of Korean descent]] [[Category:Physicians from California]] [[Category:American male television actors]] [[Category:Duke University alumni]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Male actors from Detroit]] [[Category:People from Greensboro, North Carolina]] [[Category:Male actors from New Orleans]] [[Category:University of North Carolina School of Medicine alumni]]
